item.title: Slay the Princess Sales Reach 1m, Scarlet Hollow at 100k
item.content:encoded:
Developer and publisher Black Tabby Games has revealed that its surreal horror visual novel Slay the Princess has reached a new sales milestone, and the studio has divulged sales figures for Scarlet Hollow as well.

Per a new press release, Slay the Princess has managed to reach a million sales across all platforms. As a reminder, the game launched on PC first back in October 2023 before getting itself a console release in 2024.

Black Tabby's Tony Howard-Arias says the studio, which consists of Tony and their partner Abby, is "immeasurably grateful" for the reception Slay the Princess has garnered, and they express hope that the game's success means people will realize "visual novels are a serious medium".

It's not just Slay the Princess that is celebrating a new sales milestone. Black Tabby's first game, Scarlet Hollow, has managed to hit 100,000 sales since the release of its first episode back in June 2021.

The two games are very different prospects, of course; Slay the Princess is a self-contained experience with an absurd amount of branching and reaction to player choice, while Scarlet Hollow is...well, it's also that, but it's episodic, so the whole game hasn't yet seen the light of day.

Black Tabby is working to rectify that, however. Scarlet Hollow's fifth episode is due to arrive on February 13th (that's next Friday at time of writing), and per a progress update on Steam, the episode currently "contains roughly 300,000 words", although much of that will be confined to branching paths.

If you haven't checked Slay the Princess out yet, it's a visual novel that combines distinctive pencil sketch-like art with a recursive narrative about, well, slaying a princess.

I don't want to spoil the game's many surprises, but suffice it to say there's more going on under the surface than that, so if you haven't yet, you can check it out right now on PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and Switch. Right now, Scarlet Hollow is only available for PC via Steam.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
